column4: Sorry to ask this again but can anyone give me the result of uname -r from the server and destop versions of Ubuntu

that is a silly request -- it could be anything on another person's machine -- not everyone is running the same version of the linux kernel - some old, some new, some not so old or not so new  -- what are you actually trying to do?
I am just looking for the default info, I am planning on compiling a new kernel, and wanted to see what one ubuntu default uses
so if I install the linux-image-2.6.24-16-server or linux-image package, then reboot, and select it from grub I can get the old version back ?
but beware the server image is optimized for server machines -- not ideal for desktops
my box is in a datacenter, they compiled their own version of kernel and use it with ubuntu 8.04, I would like to use the ubuntu default one, will this also work for that?
yes -- but you should choose the appropriate one for your machine and the tasks it does - is it a server machine?
yes server install, then I installed ubunut-desktop on it for gui and using nx to view gui
right, but what does your machine do primarily? serve content or cater to your desktop needs?
kinda both, gui is usually off though but nx runs if I need gui
then i would say - use the server kernel
so once again grab the server kernel deb, install it reboot and select the new kernel from grub, does this also get me header files to comppile stuff?

don't manually download and install -- use apt-get -- since it handles all the dependencies  -- yes, reboot and you should be able to choose the new kernel -- no, it does not get the headers to compile stuff -- you need the linux-headers package
whats the diff between the -generic and -386 from kernel names?
